Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Einstein Toolkit -- An Open-Source General Relativistic Multi-Physics Infrastructure for Relativistic Astrophysics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the development of the Einstein Toolkit. The Einstein Toolkit is an open-source suite of computational tools that enables interdisciplinary research in numerical relativity, general relativistic astrophysics and gravitational wave physics, and takes advantage of the emerging generation of petascale supercomputers and new cyberinfrastructure technologies. The work supported by this award adds to the Einstein Toolkit transformative new technology in adaptive mesh refinements and general relativistic magneto-hydrodynamics, thus boosting simulation capabilities and unlocking new modeling frontiers.

The computational infrastructure provided by the Einstein Toolkit has a broad positive impact on the gravitational physics and astrophysics communities. By publicly providing state-of-the-art modeling capabilities that otherwise would stay proprietary, the Einstein Toolkit maximizes the science return of funds invested in basic research. The numerical codes in the Einstein Toolkit support the quick realization of transformative computation and data-driven science stimulated by innovators entering the field. Furthermore, the Einstein Toolkit ensures the sustainability of simulation codes in numerical relativity by providing a straightforward mechanism for the migration of software to new cyberinfrastructure and technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Mertis:

The Einstein Toolkit Project (http://www.einsteintoolkit.org) provides a set of computer codes for the simulation of extreme astrophysical phenomena (e.g., supernova explosions, black hole collisions, neutron star mergers) on supercomputers. Over the 3-year duration of this project, the available codes were significantly improved and new codes were added to the Toolkit. The most important addition was the capability to simulate astrophysical magnetic fields. The increased versatility of the Einstein Toolkit computer codes has attracted many new users of the Toolkit, many of which are now actively participating in the development of new components for the Einstein Toolkit.

Many new scientific insights were gained with simulations using codes provided and maintained by the Einstein Toolkit. For example, using the new magnetic-field module, Einstein Toolkit team members researchers at the California Institute of Technology for the first time showed how magnetic field is generated in newborn neutron stars. This is an important piece in the puzzle that such extreme astrophysical objects pose.

Broader Impacts:

The Einstein Toolkit computer codes are all "open source", which means that their full source code is available for download. This allows everybody to take a detailed look at how the Einstein Toolkit codes represent the laws of physics and astrophysics. Various on-line tutorials give examples of how to use the Toolkit for astrophysical simulations (on laptops and on supercomputers). The Einstein Toolkit has also been used in the training of the next generation of computational scientists and astrophysicists in Summer Schools for undergraduate and graduate students. These students will go on to become scientists or key contributors to the nation's STEM workforce.
